Licensing

Open Source Edition


The philosophy of the OpenCPU project is to be a foundation for social, open and transparent scientific computating. The software is designed in such a way that everything stored on OpenCPU is publicly readable. Furthermore we like to create an environment where students, researchers, analyists and anyone else feels free to use, reuse, modify and learn from each others code and data, without having to worry about copyright. The OpenCPU licensing reflects this principle: you agree that code and data that you store and publish on OpenCPU become open source.


To implement this idea, OpenCPU is released under the GNU AGPLv3 license conditions. Furthermore, code and data published through OpenCPU and thereby extending its functionality, are considired derivative works and hence should be available under AGPL compatible license as well. Of course you will still be the copyright holder of your works, and you are free to release your code under any additional licenses as well, either open source or closed source. Just keep in mind that when publishing or sharing code or data on OpenCPU, you give others permission to use, reuse, modify, etc your works.


Note that it is allowed to use OpenCPU within an application that does not expose the OpenCPU API directly to the client or user. For example, OpenCPU could used as a computational backend in a similar way as e.g. a database backend like MySQL, where it is only accessed by the application layer. In a design like this, the same conditions apply: when OpenCPU is called by an application, you need to release any R code that is being used behind the scenes under an AGPL compatible license, and make it somehow available to your users. An good way would to release it in the form of an R package and publish it on CRAN or Github.


Also note that clients or applications that call the OpenCPU API are not considered derivative works. Hence, it ispossible to build a proprietary stack which interfaces to OpenCPU, as long as any R code is released under an AGPL compatible license. This way, the computations are and stay open and transparent to others, which is what open computing is all about!

Stat/dev consulting, developers of OpenCPU.
